-까요?: Used to ask a suggestion or opinion.

1.1.2 Verbs (하다, 타다, 가다, 세우다)

세우다 (to stop/park)

Example Sentences:

차를 세우다 (to stop the car)
여기서 세워 주세요. (Please stop here.)
가게 앞에 세웠어요. (I parked in front of the store.)



1.1.3 Descriptive Form (어서/아서)

-어서/아서: Indicates reason or cause, meaning “because.”

Example Sentences:

피곤해서 잠을 잤어요. (Because I was tired, I slept.)
시간이 없어서 못 갔어요. (I couldn’t go because I didn’t have time.)
배고파서 밥을 먹었어요. (I ate because I was hungry.)



1.1.4 Use of “로” to Indicate Direction (으로/로)

으로/로: Indicates direction or means.

Example Sentences:

버스로 갑시다. (Let’s go by bus.)
학교로 가요. (I’m going to school.)
오른쪽으로 가세요. (Please go to the right.)



1.1.5 Honorific Form (세요/주세요)

-세요: Used for making polite requests or instructions.

Example Sentences:

들어오세요. (Please come in.)
앉으세요. (Please sit down.)
문을 닫아 주세요. (Please close the door.)
-주세요: Used to politely ask someone to do something.

Example Sentences:

물을 주세요. (Please give me water.)
책을 읽어 주세요. (Please read the book to me.)
저를 도와 주세요. (Please help me.)

Example Sentences:

편지를 씁니다. (I write a letter.)
이 컴퓨터를 사용해도 됩니까? (Can I use this computer?)
모자를 씁니다. (I wear a hat.)

시다 (to be sour)
Example Sentences:

이 레몬은 정말 셔요. (This lemon is really sour.)

Sample Sentences:

언제든지 제 방에 들어오세요.

(You can come into my room anytime.)

질문이 있으면 언제든지 물어보세요.

(If you have any questions, feel free to ask anytime.)

(You can take a break anytime.)

Sample Sentences:

이 도시에 처음 왔지만, 길 찾기가 쉽습니다.

(It’s my first time in this city, but finding my way is easy.)

(It’s my first time taking a Korean class, but it’s very interesting.)

(I’m cooking for the first time, but I think it will go well.)


Verbs Used:

오다 (왔지만) - to come
듣다 (듣지만) - to listen, to take (a class)

Sample Sentences:

오늘은 피곤하기 때문에 일찍 잘 거예요.

(I will go to bed early today because I’m tired.)

(I took an umbrella because it’s raining.)

(The students have good grades because they study hard.)


Verbs Used:

1.2.4 Grammar Point: 잘 (well)
Sample Sentences:

2.2 Diagonalization
MIT Lecture Video: 22. Diagonalization and Powers of A






What does a diagonal matrix look like?





A diagonal matrix is a matrix in which the entries outside the main diagonal are all zero. Here is an example of a diagonal matrix:
\[\begin{pmatrix}
5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 7 \\
\end{pmatrix}\]
In this matrix, the diagonal elements are 5, 3, and 7, and all the off-diagonal elements are 0. This is the defining characteristic of a diagonal matrix.









What does it mean by “diagonalizable” in linear algebra?





In linear algebra, a matrix is said to be “diagonalizable” if it can be transformed into a diagonal matrix. Specifically, a square matrix (A) is diagonalizable if there exists an invertible matrix (P) and a diagonal matrix (D) such that:
\[
P^{-1} A P = D
\]
where (D) is a diagonal matrix. This means that the matrix (A) can be expressed in a form where all the elements outside the main diagonal are zero.









What is the relationship between Diagonalizable Matrices, Eigenvalues, and Eigenvectors?






2.2.1 Diagonalizable Matrices
A matrix ( A ) is said to be diagonalizable if it can be transformed into a diagonal matrix ( D ). This means there exists an invertible matrix ( P ) and a diagonal matrix ( D ) such that:
\[
P^{-1} A P = D
\]


2.2.2 Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors
Eigenvalues and eigenvectors are key concepts related to diagonalizable matrices:

Eigenvalues \(\lambda\): These are the values such that for a given matrix ( A ) and a non-zero vector ( ), the following equation holds: \[
A \mathbf{v} = \lambda \mathbf{v}
\]
Eigenvectors \(\mathbf{v}\): These are the non-zero vectors that satisfy the eigenvalue equation above. Each eigenvector corresponds to an eigenvalue.



2.2.3 Connecting the Concepts

Diagonalization and Eigenvalues: The diagonal elements of the matrix ( D ) are the eigenvalues of the matrix ( A ).
Matrix ( P ) and Eigenvectors: The columns of the matrix ( P ) are the eigenvectors of the matrix ( A ). If ( A ) has ( n ) linearly independent eigenvectors, then these eigenvectors form the columns of the invertible matrix ( P ).



2.2.4 Summary

A matrix ( A ) is diagonalizable if it has enough linearly independent eigenvectors to form the matrix ( P ).
The diagonal matrix ( D ) contains the eigenvalues of ( A ) along its diagonal.
The transformation \(P^{-1} A P = D\) uses the eigenvectors (forming ( P )) to diagonalize ( A ).

This relationship is crucial because diagonalizable matrices are easier to work with, especially in simplifying computations such as matrix powers and exponentials.










What are the advantages of diagonalization?





Diagonalizing a matrix provides numerous benefits, making it a powerful tool in linear algebra. Here are some of the primary advantages:

2.2.5 Simplification of Matrix Operations

Matrix Powers: Diagonal matrices are much easier to raise to a power. If ( A ) is diagonalizable, and we have ( P^{-1} A P = D ), then:
\[
A^k = P D^k P^{-1}
\]
where ( D^k ) is simply the diagonal matrix ( D ) with each diagonal element raised to the power ( k ).
Matrix Functions: Functions of matrices, such as the matrix exponential, can be computed more easily when the matrix is diagonal. For example, the exponential of ( A ) is given by:
\[
e^A = P e^D P^{-1}
\]
where ( e^D ) is the exponential of the diagonal matrix ( D ), computed by taking the exponential of each diagonal element.



2.2.6 Eigenvalue Analysis

Understanding Dynamics: In systems of differential equations, diagonalization helps to decouple the system, making it easier to analyze and solve. The eigenvalues can indicate stability and the nature of the system’s behavior.
Quantum Mechanics: In quantum mechanics, diagonalization is used to simplify the Hamiltonian operator, allowing for easier computation of the system’s energy levels and states.



2.2.7 Computational Efficiency

Efficient Computations: Algorithms that utilize diagonalization can be more computationally efficient for large matrices, as operations on diagonal matrices are simpler and faster.
Simplification in Engineering and Physics: Many problems in engineering and physics can be reduced to diagonalizable forms, simplifying both theoretical analysis and practical computations.



2.2.8 Insight into Matrix Structure

Geometric Interpretation: Diagonalization provides insights into the geometric structure of a matrix, revealing important properties through its eigenvalues and eigenvectors.



2.2.9 Summary

Matrix Powers: Easier computation of powers and functions of matrices.
System Dynamics: Simplifies analysis of dynamic systems.
Efficiency: Increases computational efficiency for large matrices.
Insights: Provides geometric and structural insights into matrices.

These advantages highlight why diagonalization is a valuable technique in various mathematical, engineering, and physical applications.










Give me a concrete example to showcase the advantages of diagonalization





Diagonalization offers numerous benefits, especially in simplifying matrix computations. Let’s demonstrate this with a concrete example.

2.2.10 Example: Diagonalizing a Matrix
Consider the matrix \(A\):
\[
A = \begin{pmatrix}
4 & 1 \\
2 & 3
\end{pmatrix}
\]

2.2.10.1 Step 1: Find the Eigenvalues
Solve the characteristic equation \(\det(A - \lambda I) = 0\):
\[
\det \begin{pmatrix}
4 - \lambda & 1 \\
2 & 3 - \lambda
\end{pmatrix} = (4 - \lambda)(3 - \lambda) - 2 = \lambda^2 - 7\lambda + 10 = 0
\]
The eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic polynomial:
\[
\lambda^2 - 7\lambda + 10 = 0
\]
Solving for \(\lambda\):
\[
\lambda = 5 \quad \text{and} \quad \lambda = 2
\]


2.2.10.2 Step 2: Find the Eigenvectors
For \(\lambda = 5\):
\[
(A - 5I) \mathbf{v} = 0
\]
\[
\begin{pmatrix}
-1 & 1 \\
2 & -2
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
x \\
y
\end{pmatrix} = 0
\]
Solving, we get \(\mathbf{v}_1 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\).
For \(\lambda = 2\):
\[
(A - 2I) \mathbf{v} = 0
\]
\[
\begin{pmatrix}
2 & 1 \\
2 & 1
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
x \\
y
\end{pmatrix} = 0
\]
Solving, we get \(\mathbf{v}_2 = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \end{pmatrix}\).


2.2.10.3 Step 3: Form the Matrices \(P\) and \(D\)
\[
P = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & -2
\end{pmatrix}, \quad D = \begin{pmatrix}
5 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix}
\]


2.2.10.4 Step 4: Verify Diagonalization
\[
P^{-1} A P = D
\]
Computing \(P^{-1}\):
\[
P^{-1} = \frac{1}{\det(P)} \begin{pmatrix}
-2 & -1 \\
-1 & 1
\end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{-3} \begin{pmatrix}
-2 & -1 \\
-1 & 1
\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}
\frac{2}{3} & \frac{1}{3} \\
\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{1}{3}
\end{pmatrix}
\]
Now,
\[
P^{-1} A P = \begin{pmatrix}
\frac{2}{3} & \frac{1}{3} \\
\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{1}{3}
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
4 & 1 \\
2 & 3
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & -2
\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}
5 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix} = D
\]



2.2.11 Application: Computing \(A^3\)
Using the diagonalization, we can compute \(A^3\) easily:
\[
A^3 = P D^3 P^{-1}
\]
First, compute \(D^3\):
\[
D^3 = \begin{pmatrix}
5 & 0 \\
0 & 2
\end{pmatrix}^3 = \begin{pmatrix}
5^3 & 0 \\
0 & 2^3
\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}
125 & 0 \\
0 & 8
\end{pmatrix}
\]
Then,
\[
A^3 = P D^3 P^{-1} = \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & -2
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
125 & 0 \\
0 & 8
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
\frac{2}{3} & \frac{1}{3} \\
\frac{1}{3} & -\frac{1}{3}
\end{pmatrix}
\]
\[
= \begin{pmatrix}
1 & 1 \\
1 & -2
\end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}
\frac{250}{3} & \frac{125}{3} \\
\frac{8}{3} & -\frac{8}{3}
\end{pmatrix}
\]
\[
= \begin{pmatrix}
\frac{258}{3} & \frac{117}{3} \\
\frac{234}{3} & \frac{141}{3}
\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}
86 & 39 \\
78 & 47
\end{pmatrix}
\]
This demonstrates how diagonalization simplifies the computation of powers of matrices.

2.3 Key Points on Diagonalizability

Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors: A matrix (A) is diagonalizable if and only if it has enough linearly independent eigenvectors to form the columns of the matrix (P). The diagonal elements of (D) are the eigenvalues of (A).
Similarity Transformation: The matrix (P) in the equation (P^{-1}AP = D) is formed from the eigenvectors of (A). This is known as a similarity transformation.
Simplification of Computations: Diagonal matrices are easier to work with, especially for raising matrices to powers and computing functions of matrices, because operations on diagonal matrices are straightforward.
Conditions for Diagonalizability: Not all matrices are diagonalizable. For instance, a matrix is diagonalizable if it has (n) linearly independent eigenvectors, where (n) is the size of the matrix.
Geometric Multiplicity: The geometric multiplicity of each eigenvalue (the number of linearly independent eigenvectors associated with it) must equal its algebraic multiplicity (the number of times it appears as a root of the characteristic polynomial) for the matrix to be diagonalizable.

In summary, a matrix being diagonalizable means it can be represented in a simpler form (a diagonal matrix) through a similarity transformation, making many matrix computations more straightforward and highlighting the structure given by the matrix’s eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

Example Sentences: 오늘은 피곤하기 때문에 일찍 잘 거예요.






오늘은 피곤하기 때문에 일찍 잘 거예요.

(I will go to bed early today because I’m tired.)

비가 오기 때문에 우산을 가져갔어요.

(I took an umbrella because it’s raining.)

학생들이 열심히 공부하기 때문에 성적이 좋습니다.

(The students have good grades because they study hard.)





Verbs Used:

피곤하다 (피곤하기 때문에) - to be tired
오다 (오기 때문에) - to come, to fall (rain)
공부하다 (공부하기 때문에) - to study

6.4 Grammar Point: 잘 (well)






Example Sentences: 그는 피아노를 잘 칩니다.






그는 피아노를 잘 칩니다.

(He plays the piano well.)

우리 팀은 프로젝트를 잘 마쳤습니다.

(She dances really well.)

마치다 (마쳤습니다) - to finish, to complete

title: 1  Learn Korean
text:
6.5 Grammar Point: 부드러워서 (because it’s gentle/soft)






Example Sentences: 그 고양이는 털이 부드러워서 만지기 좋아요.






그 고양이는 털이 부드러워서 만지기 좋아요.

(That cat’s fur is soft, so it’s nice to touch.)

그는 성격이 부드러워서 많은 친구가 있습니다.

(He has many friends because he has a gentle personality.)

음악이 부드러워서 마음이 편해집니다.

(The music is soft, so it soothes my mind.)





Verbs Used:

만지다 (만지기 좋아요) - to touch
있다 (있습니다) - to have, to exist (in the context of possessing a trait)
편해지다 (편해집니다) - to become comfortable, to relax ___

4.1 야 돼 (must/have to)






Expressing Necessity: 지금 가야 돼.






이 약을 먹어야 돼.

내일까지 숙제를 끝내야 돼.

Giving Instructions: 여기에 이름을 써야 돼.






여기에 이름을 써야 돼.

지금 떠나야 돼?

In Everyday Situations: 내일 일찍 일어나야 돼.

매일 운동해야 돼.

Expressing Permission: 여기 앉아도 돼.

(You can take pictures.)

창문 열어도 돼요?
(Can I open the window?)
조금 늦어도 돼요?

title: ChatGPT Use Cases
section: ChatGPT Usage Guidelines: Good Practice vs. Bad Practice
text:
ChatGPT Usage Guidelines: Good Practice vs. Bad Practice

Good Practice:
Code Writing and Grammar Checking: Use ChatGPT to write or debug code and check grammar, as these can be immediately verified. Non-Critical Questions: Utilize ChatGPT for emotional support, casual conversation, or drafting documents where precise correctness isn’t crucial. Verifiable Questions: Ensure there are other methods to verify ChatGPT’s responses to maintain accuracy.


Bad Practice:
Unverifiable Questions: Avoid asking ChatGPT questions where you can’t verify the correctness of the answers. Relying on Exact Answers: Do not depend on ChatGPT for answers that are crucial and cannot be verified. Blind Trust: Do not blindly trust ChatGPT’s information; always verify important details to avoid misinformation.

title: 1  Learn Korean
text:
3.1 제11화






근데 그런 말이 우리 애한테 힘이 되겠어요?





“但是，那样的话对我们孩子有帮助吗？”
힘 (力量):

그는 정말 힘이 센 사람이에요. 他是一个非常有力量的人。
힘이 되어 드리고 싶어요. 我想要给你力量。

말 (话语):

말을 조심해야 해요. 你应该小心说话。
그의 말이 맞아요. 他说的是对的。










어려운 결정할 때는 아버지 생각이 나요.





“在做困难决定的时候，我会想起父亲。”
결정 (决定):

결정을 내리기 전에 신중하게 생각해보세요. 在做决定之前，请仔细考虑。
그의 결정에 모두가 놀랐어요. 大家都对他的决定感到惊讶。

생각 (想法):

좋은 생각이 떠올랐어요. 我想到了一个好主意。
때로는 생각을 바꿔야 할 때도 있어요. 有时候需要改变想法。

나다/나오다 出，冒，起，长出, 出现，出来, 有了

새로운 문제가 나왔어요. 出现了一个新问题。

나다/나타나다 出现，显露，出面, 反映, 表达

그 사람이 어디서 나타났어요? 那个人从哪里出现的？










지금 사장님 굴욕만 중요한가요?





“现在只有老板的屈辱重要吗？”
굴욕 (屈辱):

그는 굴욕적인 상황을 겪었어요. 他经历了一种屈辱的情况。
굴욕을 극복하는 것은 쉽지 않아요. 克服羞辱并不容易。

중요하다 (重要):

건강이 가장 중요하다. 健康是最重要的。
그 정보가 결정적으로 중요했어요. 那信息是决定性的重要。










신뢰할 수 없습니다.





“不可信任。”
신뢰 (信任):

우리는 그의 신뢰를 얻었습니다. 我们赢得了他的信任。
신뢰가 성공의 열쇠입니다. 信任是成功的关键。










안아 줄게요.





“我会抱你。”
안다 (拥抱): verb

나를 안아 줘. 抱我一下。
그는 친구를 따뜻하게 안았어요. 他温暖地拥抱了朋友。










지금 내 걱정 해 주는 거야?





“你现在在担心我吗？”
걱정 (担心):

너무 걱정하지 마세요. 不要太担心。
걱정 때문에 잠을 못 잤어요. 因为担心，我没能睡觉。










니 사랑을 받을 자격이 있고?





“我有资格得到你的爱吗？”
자격 (资格):

그 일을 할 자격이 충분해요. 你有足够的资格做那件事。
자격증을 얻기 위해 시험을 봐야 해요. 为了获得资格证，我需要参加考试。










설명이 더 필요해?





“还需要更多解释吗？”
설명 (解释):

이 문제에 대한 설명을 좀 해 줄 수 있어요? 你可以解释一下这个问题吗？
좋은 설명이었어요. 那是一个很好的解释。










얘기 다 끝났습니까?





“讨论结束了吗？”
얘기 (讨论):

얘기를 좀 들어봐 줄래요? 你能听我说一下吗？
그 문제에 대한 얘기가 필요해요. 我们需要讨论那个问题。

끝나다 (kkeutnada)： 结束

회의가 끝났어요. 会议已经结束了。
이제 모든 준비가 끝났습니다. 现在所有的准备都完成了。










회사를 위해서?





“为了公司？”
위하다：为了

건강을 위해서 운동해야 해요. 为了健康你应该锻炼。
학습을 위해서 많은 시간을 할애해야 합니다. 为了学习你需要投入很多时间。

title: 1  Learn Korean
text:
2.1 제1화






영수증은 박스 위에 있습니다





“收据在盒子上面。”
重要语法点：

에 있다/없다：表示存在或不存在的状态。에 있다表示“在某地存在”，에 없다表示“在某地不存在”。

语法点例句：

가방이 의자 아래에 있습니다.（包在椅子下面。）
사람이 집에 없습니다.（家里没有人。）

高级词汇： - 영수증（收据）
高级词汇例句：

영수증을 잃어버렸어요.（我丢了收据。）
이 물건의 영수증을 보여주세요.（请给我看一下这件商品的收据。）










그러니까 너도 빨리 남친 만들어





“所以你也快点交男朋友吧。”
重要语法点：

(으)니까：表示原因或理由，相当于“因为……所以……”。

语法点例句：

날씨가 좋으니까 산책하러 갑시다.（因为天气好，所以去散步吧。）
배가 고프니까 밥 먹으러 가요.（因为肚子饿，所以去吃饭吧。）

高级词汇： - 남친（남자친구 的缩写，男朋友）
高级词汇例句：

남친과 함께 영화를 봤어요.（和男朋友一起看了电影。）
남친이 선물을 줬어요.（男朋友送了我礼物。）










주문할래? 아님 나가 줄래?





“你要点餐吗？还是你要出去？”
重要语法点：

(으)ㄹ래요：用于动词后，表示意图或意愿，相当于“要……吗？”或“想要……”。

语法点例句：

같이 갈래요?（要一起去吗？）
뭐 먹을래요?（你想吃什么？）

高级词汇： - 주문하다（点餐）
高级词汇例句：

음식은 인터넷으로 주문했어요.（食物是在网上点的。）
지금 주문할 수 있어요?（现在可以点餐吗？）










찬영아, 가자 너 내일 떠나는데





“灿荣，走吧，你明天要走了。”
重要语法点：

는데/은데/ㄴ데：用于动词或形容词后，表示背景、对比或提示下文，相当于“……但……”或“……而……”。

语法点例句：

비가 오는데 우산을 가져가세요.（下雨了，带上伞吧。）
나는 학생인데 친구는 선생님이에요.（我是学生，而朋友是老师。）

高级词汇： - 떠나다（离开）
高级词汇例句：

그는 어제 서울을 떠났어요.（他昨天离开了首尔。）
나는 내일 아침에 떠날 거예요.（我明天早上要走。）










차은상 싫어 정말 싫어, 완전 싫어, 매우 싫어!





“车恩尚讨厌，真的讨厌，完全讨厌，非常讨厌！”
重要语法点：

싫어하다：表示讨厌或不喜欢，用于描述对某事物或某人的负面情感。

语法点例句：

나는 매운 음식을 싫어해요.（我讨厌辣的食物。）
그는 아침에 일찍 일어나는 것을 싫어해요.（他讨厌早上早起。）

高级词汇： - 완전（完全）
高级词汇例句：

이 영화는 완전 재미있어요.（这部电影完全有趣。）
오늘 하루가 완전 피곤했어요.（今天一天完全累坏了。）










학교는 잘 다니고 있어?





“学校上得好吗？”
重要语法点：

고 있다：表示正在进行的动作，相当于“正在……”。

语法点例句：

지금 책을 읽고 있어요.（现在正在看书。）
친구와 통화하고 있어요.（正在和朋友通话。）

高级词汇：

다니다（上，去，来回）

高级词汇例句：

그는 매일 도서관에 다녀요.（他每天去图书馆。）
나는 이 회사에 3년 동안 다녔어요.（我在这家公司上班已经三年了。）










돈 좀 보태실래요?





“能帮忙凑点钱吗？”
重要语法点： - (으)실래요：用于动词后，表示礼貌的提议或询问，相当于“您要……吗？”。
语法点例句：

같이 가실래요?（您要一起去吗？）
이걸 드실래요?（您要吃这个吗？）

高级词汇： - 보태다（凑，加）
高级词汇例句：

친구들이 돈을 보태서 선물을 샀어요.（朋友们凑钱买了礼物。）
그가 내게 돈을 좀 보태줬어요.（他给我凑了点钱。）










미국에 있는 아들이 계속 전화를 안 받는 모양이에요





“在美国的儿子好像一直不接电话。”
重要语法点：

는데/은데/ㄴ데：用于动词或形容词后，表示背景、对比或提示下文，相当于“……但……”或“……而……”。

语法点例句：

비가 오는 모양이에요.（外面好像在下雨。）
그는 오늘 바쁜 모양이에요.（他今天好像很忙。）

高级词汇：

계속（继续，一直）
받다（接，接受）

高级词汇例句：

그는 계속 일하고 있어요.（他一直在工作。）
그녀는 나의 전화를 받지 않았어요.（她没接我的电话。）










사장님 들어오셨어요





“社长进来了。”
重要语法点：

(으)셨어요：用于动词或形容词后，表示敬语的过去式，相当于“……了”或“……过了”。

语法点例句：

할아버지께서 식사하셨어요.（爷爷吃过饭了。）
선생님께서 말씀하셨어요.（老师说过话了。）

高级词汇： - 들어오다（进来）
高级词汇例句：

그는 방에 들어왔어요.（他进了房间。）
손님이 가게에 들어오셨어요.（客人进了店。）










점심을 늦게 먹었어요





“午饭吃晚了。”
重要语法点：

았/었어요：用于动词或形容词后，表示过去式，相当于“……了”。

语法点例句：

어제 친구를 만났어요.（昨天见了朋友。）
우리는 영화를 봤어요.（我们看了电影。）

高级词汇： - 늦다（晚）
高级词汇例句：

회의에 늦었어요.（开会迟到了。）
버스가 늦게 왔어요.（公交车来得很晚。）










오늘 제 방 청소 누가 하셨어요?





“今天谁打扫了我的房间？”
重要语法点：

(으)셨어요：用于动词或形容词后，表示敬语的过去式，相当于“……了”或“……过了”。

语法点例句：

할머니께서 아침을 만드셨어요.（奶奶做了早餐。）
선생님께서 그 책을 읽으셨어요.（老师读了那本










다시 하세요

title: 2  Math Review: Linear Algebra
text:
2.2 Definitions and Setup

Matrix \(A\): a square matrix of size \(n \times n\).
Matrix \(S\): a matrix \(S = [v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n]\) where each column vector \(v_i\) is an eigenvector of \(A\). Thus, \(S\) is \(n \times n\).
Matrix \(V\): a diagonal matrix \(V = \text{diag}(\lambda_1, \lambda_2, \ldots, \lambda_n)\), where \(\lambda_i\) is the eigenvalue corresponding to the eigenvector \(v_i\) in \(S\).


2.2.1 Eigenvector and Eigenvalue Relationship
For each eigenvector \(v_i\) of \(A\), the corresponding eigenvalue equation is: \[ A v_i = \lambda_i v_i \]


2.2.2 Matrix Multiplication \(AS\)
When we multiply \(A\) by \(S\), we are essentially multiplying \(A\) by each eigenvector \(v_i\) in \(S\): \[ AS = A[v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n] = [A v_1, A v_2, \ldots, A v_n] \]
Using the eigenvalue relationship: \[ AS = [\lambda_1 v_1, \lambda_2 v_2, \ldots, \lambda_n v_n] \]


2.2.3 Matrix Multiplication \(SV\)
Multiplying \(S\) by \(V\), where \(V\) is diagonal, we scale each column vector \(v_i\) of \(S\) by the corresponding diagonal entry \(\lambda_i\) of \(V\): \[ SV = [v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n] \begin{bmatrix} \lambda_1 & 0 & \ldots & 0 \\ 0 & \lambda_2 & \ldots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \ldots & \lambda_n \end{bmatrix} \] \[ SV = [\lambda_1 v_1, \lambda_2 v_2, \ldots, \lambda_n v_n] \]


2.2.4 Comparing \(AS\) and \(SV\)
From the results above: \[ AS = [\lambda_1 v_1, \lambda_2 v_2, \ldots, \lambda_n v_n] \] \[ SV = [\lambda_1 v_1, \lambda_2 v_2, \ldots, \lambda_n v_n] \]
Thus: \[ AS = SV \]


2.2.5 Conclusion
The equation \(AS = SV\) holds true under the condition that the columns of \(S\) are the eigenvectors of \(A\), and the entries of \(V\) are the corresponding eigenvalues. This equality shows that each eigenvector of \(A\) is scaled by its corresponding eigenvalue when multiplied by \(A\), which aligns with the definition of eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
This proof forms the basis for the spectral decomposition of matrices and is fundamental in linear algebra, especially in fields like quantum mechanics, vibration analysis, and more.
